LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower      Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
 
Classification     Targeting classification: General intervention 
Themes: Economic growth 
      Subthemes:  Inclusive  social  development,  Good  governance, 
Private sector development  
 
Environment Assessment  Category C   
Environmental  implications  were  reviewed,  and  no  significant 
adverse environmental impacts identified. 
 
Program Description  The  program  loan  will  support  implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction Program outlined under the multi-development partner 
funded Poverty Reduction Support Credit III (PRSC III), as part of 
the Government’s overall Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and 
Growth Strategy (CPRGS). 
 
Rationale  Over the last decade the Government has quickly reduced poverty 
and achieved a high level of economic growth. Poverty reduction 
largely resulted from economic growth, which created jobs and 
provided  better  livelihoods.  To  ensure  continuing  poverty 
reduction and economic growth, the Government needs to lock-in 
policy reforms, remove remaining structural weaknesses, promote 
socially inclusive development, and modernize governance and 
the public administration system.  
 
The CPRGS provides a framework for poverty reduction policies, 
programs, and actions in Viet Nam, and has been adopted as the 
reference document by the official development assistance (ODA) 
community  for  planning  external  assistance.  Several  ODA 
partners including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), support 
the  CPRGS.  The  CPRGS  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  poverty 
reduction  strategy;  and  its  country  strategy  and  program,  and 
poverty partnership agreement with Viet Nam.  
 
World  Bank  support  includes  three  PRSCs,  approved  in  2002 
(US$250  million),  2003  (US$100  million),  and  2004  (US$100 
million). The focus of these operations has gradually shifted from 
reform  of  state-owned  commercial  banks  and  the  state-owned 
enterprise (SOE) sector to a broader policy agenda, covering a 
number  of  sectors  and  issues  affecting  poverty  reduction  and 
growth in Viet Nam.  
 
The ODA community in Viet Nam considers the PRSC a useful 
instrument for supporting CPRGS implementation. In 2004, major 
ODA partners such as Canada, Denmark, European Commission, 
Japan,  Netherlands,  and  United  Kingdom  are  cofinancing  the 
PRSC III with the World Bank.

ii  
       
ADB has been actively involved in formulating the PRSC III. ADB 
has  promoted  policy  dialogue  on  similar  issues  through  its 
program lending activities and sector policy reforms. The PRSC III 
complements ADB support to Viet Nam for policy and institutional 
reform. As a multisector instrument covering a range of issues 
related to poverty reduction, the PRSC framework provides ADB 
with  an  opportunity  to  (i)  advance  and  widen  national  policy 
dialogue in a well-coordinated and comprehensive manner, (ii) 
provide lending and nonlending assistance in coordination with 
other ODA partners, and (iii) ensure key policy issues important 
for  the  implementation  of  ADB  operations  in  Viet  Nam  are 
adequately  considered  and  addressed  in  the  policy  dialogue 
between the Government and the ODA community to help achieve 
the common goal of poverty reduction and growth. 
  
The proposed program loan adheres to ADB’s recent endeavors 
to  adopt  program-based  and  sector  approaches  in  its  lending 
operations to reduce transaction costs for its developing member 
countries  as  well  as  for  its  own  operations.  The  approach  is 
consistent  with  ADB’s  reform  agenda;  Long-Term  Strategic 
Framework,  and  Medium-Term  Strategy,  and  will  directly  help 
fulfill ADB’s obligations to the Rome Declaration on harmonizing 
procedures of multilateral development banks. 
 
 
Objectives and Scope  The main goal of the program loan is to help reduce poverty and 
sustain high-level economic growth, as envisaged in the CPRGS. 
The  purpose  is  to  provide  support  for  implementation  of  the 
Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Program  within  the  policy 
framework  of  the  PRSC  III,  focusing  on  reducing  structural 
weaknesses  and  improving  business  environment  for  private 
sector  development,  promoting  socially  inclusive  development, 
and modernizing governance.  
 
The program loan will strengthen Viet Nam’s reform program on 
three fronts: 
 
(i)  Promote  growth  and  create  employment  by  increasing 
internal  and  external  competition,  accelerating  the 
divestiture of SOEs and state-owned commercial banks, 
and  improving  transparency  and  accountability  in  SOE 
operations and in banking and the financial sector.  
(ii)  Advance  human  development  by  increasing  the  budget 
appropriation  for  education  and  adopting  higher  quality 
education  standards;  increasing  resources  to  cover  the 
health care costs of the poor; developing mechanisms to 
complete  the  transfer  of  land-use  rights  to  households, 
especially  in  upland  and  ethnic  minority  areas;  and 
supporting measures to improve environmental and water 
resources management.

iii
                          
(iii)  Increase  transparency  and  accountability  of  public 
finances;  promote  simplified  administrative  procedures, 
and take measures to eliminate corruption as part of a 
broader effort to build modern governance; and revamp 
the planning processes, moving away from a command 
approach  to  aligning  policies  and  resources  with  the 
attainment of well-specified development goals based on 
empirical analysis and wider consultations. 
 
Cost Estimates  The  Government’s  estimation  of  the  financing  gap  for 
implementing the CPRGS for 2004 is US$3.3 billion. ODA and 
foreign  direct  investment  inflows  are  expected  to  meet  the 
financing gap. The estimated costs of some specific programs are 
(i) health funds for the poor— US$50 million annually for the next 
3 years; (ii) increase in spending on education from 15.8% to 
17.3%  of  the  Government  budget—at  least  US$20  million 
annually for 2004; and (iii) resolution of nonperforming loans and 
other related costs—about US$2 billion in total throughout the 
program. 
 
Financing Plan  A total of about US$178 million is expected to be funded through 
ODA  resources  in  2004.  Led  by  the  World  Bank,  which  has 
already approved a US$100 million credit from the International 
Development  Association  to  support  the  PRSC  III,  other 
cofinanciers,  include  the  Canadian  International  Development 
Agency (Can$6.3 million grant), Denmark (US$10 million grant), 
the European Commission (€15 million grant), the Japan Bank for 
International  Cooperation  (US$18  million  equivalent  loan), 
Netherlands  (€4  million  grant),  and  the  United  Kingdom’s 
Department for International Development (₤20 million grant). 
 
Loan Amount and Terms  A loan of US$6.4 million from ADB’s Special Funds resources will 
be provided. The loan will have a 24-year term including a grace 
period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0 % during the grace period 
and 1.5 % during the amortization period, and such other terms 
and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The loan 
proceeds may be used to finance eligible imports incurred within 
180 days prior to the date of loan effectiveness. The loan reflects 
ADB’s support for implementation of the CPRGS following the 
policy framework of the PRSC III program. The loan will contribute 
to financing the adjustment costs resulting from implementation of 
the policy matrix, particularly the prior actions for the PRSC III, 
and will support and facilitate the Government’s continued and 
deepened reform program for poverty reduction. 
 
Disbursement  The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon declaration of 
loan effectiveness.  
 
Utilization Period                  The loan will be fully utilized by 31 December 2005.

iv   
Executing Agency  State Bank of Viet Nam, will be the Executing Agency, which also 
works in close collaboration with the World Bank to prepare and 
implement the PRSCs. 
 
Implementation     Program  management  comprises  three  main  arrangements.  In           
Arrangements             2002,  the  National  Steering  Committee  was  established  to                        
                                      implement the CPRGS and PRSCs. It  is  chaired by a first deputy                        
prime minister  and the   standing vice-chair is a deputy governor 
of the SBV. The steering committee has several representatives 
from key economic ministries, such as the ministries of agriculture 
and rural development; education and training; finance; justice; 
labor, invalids, and social affairs; and trade; as well as Office of 
the  Government;  Party's  Economic  Commission;  and  SBV; 
representing the PRSC III’s policy reform areas.  
    
An interministerial working group and secretariat to implement and 
monitor  the  CPRGS  has  been  established  at  the  Ministry  of 
Planning and Investment. The group comprises representatives 
from  key  economic  ministries  that  represent  the  policy  reform 
areas  under  the  PRSC  III.    SBV  coordinates  PRSC 
implementation. 
 
Monitoring and Reporting  Viet Nam continues to make good use of information and analysis 
in  policy  making  and  developing  individual  components  of  the 
Arrangements 
PRSC program. The PRSC III builds on this experience, in terms 
of streamlining the numerous ongoing monitoring and evaluation 
initiatives. Key sources of monitoring information for poverty and 
program outcomes include the household living standard survey, 
periodic participatory poverty and governance assessments, the 
small  business  registration  survey,  public  expenditure  tracking 
survey, as well as quarterly progress reports from relevant sector 
ministries  and  committees  implementing  the  PRSC  reform 
program.  
 
In addition, the strengthening of management information systems 
for  SOEs  and  for  all  public  spending,  both  led  by  Ministry  of 
Finance,  is  an  integral  part  of  the  PRSC  program.  Efforts  for 
provincial implementation of the CPRGS rely on the development 
of appropriate monitoring indicators as well. Gradually, the number 
of indicators has been narrowed to around 40, roughly 100 less 
than  when  the  process  started.  Many  of  the  indicators  in  this 
narrower set will be generated using the new household living 
standard surveys (which began in 2002). It will also provide semi-
annual progress reports on the proposed program loan. 
 
The Government will prepare and present a semi-annual progress 
report to ADB. ADB will participate in all joint assessments by the 
Government and development partners on the outcomes of the 
PRSC III and PRSC IV triggers (measures and actions).

v
                          
Procurement   The loan proceeds will be utilized in accordance with the simplified 
disbursement procedures and related requirements for program 
loans.  Goods  and  services  produced  and  originating  in  ADB 
member  countries  will  be  procured,  with  due  consideration  for 
economy  and  efficiency,  in  accordance  with  standard  public 
procedures in Viet Nam, and normal private sector commercial 
practices  acceptable  to  ADB.  Goods  commonly  traded  on  the 
international commodity markets will be procured in accordance 
with procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB. 
 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed for a broad range of imports, 
subject to a negative list of ineligible items. Loan proceeds will be 
disbursed  on  the  basis  of  a  certification  provided  by  the 
Government  the  value  of  total  imports  minus  (i)  imports  from 
nonmember  countries,  (ii)  ineligible  imports,  and  (iii)  imports 
financed under other ODA, is equal to or greater than the amount 
expected to be disbursed during the year. 
 
Counterpart Funds   The counterpart funds to be generated from the loan proceeds will 
be  used  to  finance  the  adjustment  costs  of  implementing  the 
reform program as per the policy matrix. 
 
Social Issues  No significant adverse impacts relating to social issues (ethnic 
minorities and gender), resettlement, and poverty are expected. 
   
Program Benefits     Policy reform actions will improve transparency and accountability                  
and Beneficiaries  in SOE operations and in banking subsector. The establishment of 
a  sound  regulatory  framework  for  policy  resulting  in  increased 
private investment and exports will lead to additional job creation. 
The policy reform will promote human development by improving 
the  access  of  the  poor  to  education  and  health  care,  and 
increasing the security of asset ownership through a new land law. 
By addressing several gaps in the Budget Law, it will increase 
transparency and accountability of public finances, and improve 
legal transparency and accessibility, thus laying the foundations 
for a state ruled by law. Decentralized public administration and 
increased beneficiary participation are other expected benefits. 
     
Risks  and  Assumptions  Through  appropriate  measures  and  proactive  programs,  the     
Government will need to mitigate the potential adverse economic, 
social, and environmental impacts of increased trade openness, 
reduced  number  of  state  enterprises,  and  liberalized  land 
transactions.  
 
Regarding potential program risks, incomplete structural reform 
could  jeopardize  growth  and  stability  in  the  longer  term. 
Haphazard introduction of market forces in the social sectors, and 
the trend to decentralization have put a strain on service delivery. 
At the same time, fast integration with the world economy may 
lead to increased inequality, at least temporarily, as the benefits

vi   
accrue to specific regions and skills disproportionately. Growth in 
Viet Nam could become less equitable in the years to come. 
 
A fiduciary risk is associated with the PRSC III, if progress on 
enhancing  budget  transparency  and  tackling  corruption  is 
inadequate. However, the Government has already started taking 
measures to enhance fiscal transparency and to curb corruption. 
Their full implementation will be crucial to mitigate the fiduciary 
risk.

I.  THE PROPOSAL
 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Support to Implementation of Poverty Reduction 
Program. The loan follows a program-based approach and is part of the jointly processed multi- 
development partner-funded Poverty Reduction Support Credit III (PRSC III) in support of the 
Government's Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS). The program 
framework is in Appendix1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.   The Government of Viet Nam believes that poverty reduction is the basic element in 
ensuring social justice and sustainable growth, and that high and sustainable growth could bring 
about the physical energy to support and provide opportunities for the poor. The Government 
therefore places poverty reduction as an overarching objective in its national socioeconomic 
development process. To reaffirm its commitment to poverty reduction, the Government signed 
a poverty reduction partnership agreement with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 2002. 
The Government also has committed to achieving the Millennium Development Goals. 
 
A.  Development Objectives, Strategies, and Plans 
 
3.  The CPRGS reflects the Government’s commitment to inclusive economic and social 
development.  It  elaborates  all  general  objectives,  institutional  arrangements,  policies,  and 
programs  of  the  10-year  Socioeconomic  Development  Strategy  (2001–2010)  and  5-year 
Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (2001–2005)  with  detailed  specific  action  plans.  Unlike 
previous development plans, which followed a command approach to economic management, 
the  CPRGS  is  based  on  empirical  analysis  and  broad  consultation.  It  spells  out  clear 
development goals, identifies the policies to attain them, aligns resources to those policies, and 
establishes  an  appropriate  monitoring  and  evaluation  system.  In  2003,  the  CPRGS  was 
expanded to address issues related to large-scale infrastructure and poverty reduction. The 
three main pillars of the CPRGS are (i) completing the transition to a market economy, (ii) 
keeping development inclusive and sustainable, and (iii) building modern governance. These 
are consistent with ADB’s poverty reduction strategy1—pro-poor growth, social development 
and  good  governance;  and  its  country  strategy  and  program  (2002–2004)2  and  poverty 
partnership agreement with Viet Nam.3 The CPRGS is widely recognized as a blueprint for 
development with strong national ownership. The CPRGS approach will be mainstreamed into 
the next 5-year development plan, to be issued in 2006. Details on the CPRGS are given in 
Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Recent Economic Performance  
4.  Viet Nam continues to enjoy robust economic growth and impressive poverty reduction. 
The economy doubled in size during the last decade, while the poverty rate was halved. Per 
capita gross domestic product (GDP) grew by around 6% per year on average during that 
period, in spite of the Asian financial crisis. GDP increased by 7.1% in 2003, and is expected to

domestic demand and fast export growth. Exports are growing by 15% to 20% per year in value

around 25% of GDP, with private investment accounting for an increasingly large share of total

III.  THE SECTOR  
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
  1.   Progress with Reducing Poverty 
5.  The  last  decade  was  characterized  by  substantial  progress  in  the  lives  of  the 
Vietnamese population. Viet Nam halved poverty in about 10 years. The number of people living 
in poverty decreased from 58% in 1993 to 37% in 1998 and to 29% in 2002. Social indicators 
improved markedly, indicating Viet Nam is well-positioned to attain key Millennium Development 
Goals.  Poverty  reduction  has  always  been  underpinned  by  reasonably  rapid,  stable,  and 
inclusive economic growth. A recent joint poverty assessment study indicates that the elasticity 
of poverty reduction has been higher than one, e.g., a growth rate of per capita output of about 
6%  was  associated  with  reduction  in  poverty  of  about  7%.  However,  the  rate  of  poverty 
reduction has slowed in recent years (2 percentage points) from that of the first half of the last 
decade (4 percentage points).5 Poverty reduction is slow or unchanged in northern mountains, 
central highlands, and in pockets of the Red River and Mekong deltas, contributing to regional 
income disparity. Poverty incidence is perpetual and chronic in cross-border areas.  
 
6.  Although Viet Nam (like many other countries in the region) has had high economic 
growth rates, about 29% of the population still lives in poverty. Addressing the poverty of these 
people will be more difficult than before because of their remote location.6 Poverty in some of 
these regions, such as the Central Highlands, is entrenched; social tensions and instability 
                                                 
4 ADB. 2004. Asian Development Outlook Update 2004. Manila. 
5  World Bank. 2003. Viet Nam Development Report 2004—Poverty. (A joint publication of development partners, 
including ADB.) Hanoi. 
6  In addition, the benefits from allocating land to households are already generally realized.

3
could place additional obstacles for economic growth. Any trickle-down effect, if and when it 
happens,  may  come  too  late  for  these  areas  and  poor  people.  Thus  a  carefully  targeted 
approach (in terms of planning and delivery) will be required to reduce poverty. 
 
7.  Poverty reduction efforts must (i) focus on high impact and sustainable poverty reduction 
programs and projects (i.e., asset creating and/or income-generating activities); and (ii) improve 
access to markets through infrastructure development, and basic health and education services 
to poor people and their children. Forests, water resources, and tourism/ecotourism should and 
can play an important role in moving, and keeping, these communities out of poverty. 
 
  2.   The Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy  
 
8.  In  May  2002,  Viet  Nam  embarked  on  CPRGS  implementation.  The  CPRGS  was 
prepared  with  support  of  the  development  assistance  community,  including  ADB,  and  in 
consultation with stakeholders and civil society (Appendix 2 provides details). Implementation of 
the policy reform agenda as stipulated in the CPRGS, has been largely through pooling of 
official development assistance (ODA) resources, both grant and lending, under the PRSC 
framework,  prepared  by  the  development  partners  in  close  consultation  with  government 
agencies, and the Government’s own resources. The World Bank leads the PRSC reviews and 
processing, with active participation by other major development partners, including ADB. The 
focus of these operations has gradually shifted from narrowly defined structural reform, such as 
the reform of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) and the state-owned enterprise (SOE) 
sector to a broader and deeper policy reform agenda, encompassing the three pillars of the 
CPRGS and embracing many sectors and issues related to sustainable poverty reduction and 
economic growth.  
 
9.  The  Government  has  well-established  coordinating,  monitoring,  and  oversight 
arrangements for poverty reduction programs funded by various ODA resources. The National 
Steering Committee, established in September 2002, is chaired by a deputy prime minister, with 
a deputy governor of the State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) as standing deputy chair. Its members 
come from all concerned government ministries and agencies. The steering committee guides 
implementation of the poverty reduction programs under the CPRGS, the International Monetary 
Fund’s Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility,7 and the PRSC. The Government undertakes 
detailed reviews of implementation progress of the CPRGS reform agenda, and discusses 
findings and emerging issues with its development assistance partners, usually at the annual 
Consultative Group meeting.  
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
  1.   Process and Implementation Performance 
 
10.  Overall, CPRGS progress has been significant, but important structural issues and social 
challenges need to be addressed. Regarding the transition to a market economy, the reform 
agenda has relied on restructuring the state sector, and not on massive divestiture. Important 
steps have been undertaken, especially in terms of liberalizing trade and fostering competition. 
But addressing hard budget constraints faced by the SOEs has proved more difficult. On the 
social side, regional disparities may widen as Viet Nam integrates with the world economy. Also, 
ethnic minorities have benefited less from economic growth than the majority of the population. 
                                                 
7  The Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility ended on 12 April 2004. The International Monetary Fund continues its 
presence in the country, providing advice to the Government on macroeconomic management and tax issues.

4  
The effective delivery of social services to the poor, especially for disadvantaged regions and 
ethnic minorities, is essential to keep development inclusive. But reform in the social sectors 
requires changes in their financing, and needs to be carefully sequenced and aligned with the 
decentralization  process.  As  for  governance,  institutional  reform  lags  the  rapid  economic 
transition, creating opportunities for abuse. The Government has recently taken measures to 
strengthen the State Inspectorate and State Audit. An ambitious initiative to strengthen public 
financial management is under way. But considerable weaknesses persist in the selection of 
public investment projects; in the integration of capital and recurrent expenditures; and in the 
supervision of project implementation, especially at the local level. Weak financial management 
systems  and  insufficient  transparency  create  the  risk  of  inefficiency  in  the  allocation  of 
resources, mismanagement, and corruption. 
 
11.   In 2003 major movements and initiatives were undertaken on a broad range of reforms, 
especially in relation to integrating with the world economy, permitting public investment in large 
SOEs and SOCBs, and designing a new approach to fight corruption. The Government is 
committed to following these activities through as they promise to solidify and accelerate the 
needed reforms. The Government is also committed to adopting a more decisive stance on 
banking reform. As part of this, the Government will outline a clear separation of the functions of 
SBV  as  owner  of  commercial  banks  and  supervisor  of  the  system,  and  take  actions  to 
restructure the SOCBs and improve their credit culture. The Government recognizes that for it to 
increase lending from the ODA community, it will need to expedite implementation of its recent 
decision  on  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO);  increase  private  sector 
investment  in  large  SOEs  and  SOCBs;  tackle  directed  lending;  and  make  progress  on 
governance and public administration reforms, the anticorruption agenda, as well as financial 
sector reform.  
 
2.  Country Strategy and Program of the Asian Development Bank 
 
12.  ADB’s poverty reduction strategy is based on three pillars: (i) pro-poor economic growth, 
(ii) social development, and (iii) good governance. ADB’s Country Strategy and Program for Viet 
Nam,  approved  in  January  2002,  emphasizes  (i)  generating  economic  growth  and  new 
employment  through  private  sector  development;  (ii)  improving  governance  and  public 
administration; and (iii) paying attention to socially inclusive development and focusing on the 
central region, where the incidence of poverty remains high (footnote 2).  
 
13.  The joint poverty assessment completed in 2003 by the Government and a number of 
development partners, including ADB,8 confirmed that economic growth continues to reduce 
poverty in Viet Nam, but that since the pace of poverty reduction is slowing, targeting of the poor 
is becoming more necessary. At the same time, to deal successfully with the accelerating pace 
of  international  economic  integration,  Viet  Nam  needs  to  modernize  its  economy  and 
institutions, and accelerate investment (to an estimated 35% of GDP). Faster growth, which is 
likely  to  benefit  the  more  advanced  areas,  will  need  to  be  accompanied  by  measures  to 
distribute the benefits of growth, including targeting on poor areas and groups.  
  3.  Lessons Learned  
    a.  Multi-Development Partner Supported Poverty Reduction Programs

Group meeting, 2–3 December 2003. Hanoi.

5
14.  The  World  Bank-led  and  multi-development  partner-funded  PRSC  program  was 
introduced to Viet Nam in 2001. The PRSC I was a two-tranche US$250 million credit from the 
International  Development  Association  approved  by  the  World  Bank,  based  on  the 
Government’s interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper. The PRSC I was a structural reform 
program focusing on (i) liberalizing trade, (ii) reforming SOEs, (iii) strengthening banking, (iv) 
improving the private sector environment, and (v) improving management and transparency in 
public finance. It was cofinanced by four bilateral funding agencies with grants equivalent to 
US$43 million (Denmark—DKr78 million; Netherlands—€15 million; Sweden—€2 million; and 
United Kingdom—₤14 million).9 The PRSC II, was a one-tranche operation for a US$100 million 
credit from the International Development Association, approved by the World Bank in June 
2003. In addition to continued support for structural reforms, the PRSC II had a broader policy 
reform  agenda,  including  inclusive  development  and  building  modern  governance.  It  was 
cofinanced  by  three  development  agencies  with  the  equivalent  grant  of  US$31  million 
(Denmark— DKr19 million, Netherlands—€8 million, and United Kingdom—₤10 million.  
 
15.  The assessment of the first two PRSC programs showed that progress was achieved 
within most sectors, but with room for improvement, particularly for SOE and financial sector 
reform. Reducing SOE budgets and strengthening incentives for restructuring were the main 
outstanding issues facing the SOE sector. In the financial sector, progress was uneven. The 
progress in reforming the SOCBs, including the resolution of nonperforming loans was slow and 
not transparent. Directed lending increased rapidly through the Development Assistance Fund, 
while the ability of credit risk assessment improved rather slowly. Improving the quality of new 
credit remained a key issue in banking reform. Broadening the program scope from structural 
adjustment to a comprehensive poverty reduction and growth program was recommended. 
 
    b.  Asian Development Bank Policy-Based Lending 
 
16.  Lessons from the experience of previous program loans and postevaluation studies are 
that (i) continued ownership and commitment of government are fundamental to achieving 
development outcomes; (ii) monitoring and evaluation should be based on both process (inputs 
and outputs) and outcome indicators; (iii) outcome indicators will depend on successful follow-
on actions (as passage of a decree or law alone will not produce any meaningful results if the 
law  is  not  brought  into  effect  (which  will  require  regulations,  circulars,  etc.,)  and  proper 
enforcement (which will require institutional capabilities); and (iv) sector or subsector-based 
program loans have limited scope to address economy-wide policy and institutional issues. 
 
4.  Justification for the Poverty Reduction Support Credit III 
 
17.  The PRSC III aims to address three key areas of macro policy and institutional reforms 
for (i) supporting the transition to a market economy by removing structural weaknesses and 
improving  the  business  environment,  (ii)  making  development  socially  inclusive  and 
environment friendly, and (iii) modernizing governance and the public administration system. 
The preparation of the PRSC III was expected to build on the foundations of the existing strong 
ODA  community’s  commitment  to  support  Viet  Nam’s  reform  agenda  through  nationwide 
implementation  of  the  CPRGS,  and  galvanize  interest  for  the  reform  program  among 
stakeholders.  Increasingly  development  partners  have  united  around  the  PRSC  as  an 
instrument  for  policy  dialogue.  They  have  already  been  actively  involved  in  supporting 
implementation of the reform agenda, through analytical work, technical assistance, project 
lending, and direct budget support. The PRSCs, including the PRSC III, fall in the last category. 
                                                 
9  DKr = Danish kroner, € = euro, ₤ = pound sterling.

6  
The rationale for direct budget support comes from the external financing requirements of Viet 
Nam, estimated at about US$3.3 billion in 2004, to be met mainly through disbursements of 
ODA and foreign direct investment inflows. Some of the policy actions supported by the PRSC 
process entail a substantial additional burden on the budget. Among these are recapitalization 
of SOCBs, operation of a safety net for workers who become redundant as a result of SOE 
restructuring, expansion of budget appropriations for the education sector, and creation of 
provincial health care funds for the poor.  
18.  The  justification  for  the  PRSC  III  is  grounded  on  three  criteria:  (i)  prudent 
macroeconomic management to ensure that progress with the long-term reform agenda will not 
be undermined by short-term instability; (ii) the Government’s own assessment of the progress 
accomplished in CPRGS implementation; and (iii) the reform triggers (measures and actions) for 
the  PRSC  III  (established  with  the  PRSC  II),  need  to  be  met,  except  for  unforeseen 
circumstances.  
 
19.  The International Monetary Fund’s assessment of Viet Nam’s economic performance10 
confirmed the country’s solid macroeconomic performance. The Governments’ progress report11 
on CPRGS implementation was presented to the Consultative Group meeting in December 
2003. The report highlights the accomplishments in reform implementation (e.g., opening of the 
economy, more favorable investment climate, better public financial management, substantial 
poverty reduction, and attainment of the Millennium Development Goals), but it also points out 
bottlenecks in structural reform and key outstanding social issues (e.g., growing inequalities, 
poverty  among  ethnic  minorities,  rural-urban  migrants,  and  challenges  in  promoting  good 
governance and combating corruption. The joint staff assessment of the CPRGS led by the 
World Bank and observations by other key development partners acknowledges the frankness 
in reporting and also notes the challenges. The assessment indicates that the progress was 
generally satisfactory or highly satisfactory for all triggers related to the second (social inclusion 
and environmental sustainability) and third (modern governance) pillars, while the progress was 
noted markedly uneven in relation to the first pillar (transition to a market economy). Slow 
progress was noted for SOE and SOCB reforms. 
 
5.  Rationale for the Proposed Program Loan 
 
20.  The PRSC III, which was jointly processed by major development partners including 
ADB, further deepens the reforms supported by the PRSCs I and II, and the Poverty Reduction 
and Growth Facility. The policy actions it endorses are all firmly rooted in the three pillars of the 
CPRGS.  It  also  identifies  actions  to  support  the  unfinished  reform  agenda,  including  the 
preparations for WTO accession, opening of the equity capital of large SOEs and SOCBs to 
private investors, progress in planning processes and public financial management, and the 
move toward a more systemic approach to addressing corruption. In addition, the PRSC III 
policy agenda includes several measures to promote socially inclusive economic development. 
These are consistent with ADB’s poverty reduction strategy, Country Strategy and Program for 
Viet Nam, and poverty reduction agreement with Viet Nam. 
 
21.  CPRGS implementation supported by PRSC program is expected to lead to substantial 
improvements in development outcomes. The current PRSC-cycle covers 5 years, much the
