7
same as the CPRGS. While the reform program focuses on a set of strategic policy actions, its 
implementation should translate into improved economic and social indicators. The preparatory 
work  for  the  PRSC  III  commenced  late  in  2003.  In  the  area  of  diagnostics,  the  poverty 
assessment12 using both 2003 household data and participatory poverty assessments was a 
major accomplishment. The PRSC III was processed during the first quarter of 2004. ADB 
participated in the diagnostic exercise on poverty as well as in the formulation of the PRSC III.  
 
22.  The ODA community has adopted the CPRGS as their reference document for planning 
external assistance for the country. The focus of these operations has gradually broadened to 
include all the essential pillars of poverty reduction and sustainable economic growth, and are 
incorporated in PRSC programs. The ODA community in Viet Nam considers the PRSC a useful 
instrument  in  support  of  CPRGS  implementation.  Six  development  assistance  partners—
Canada, Denmark, European Commission, Japan, Netherlands, and the United Kingdom—are 
cofinancing the PRSC III with the World Bank in 2004. Appendix 3 provides the aid coordination 
matrix. 
 
23.  ADB has promoted policy dialogue in Viet Nam on similar issues at the sector level 
through  its  program  lending  activities  (such  as  loans  for  the  Agriculture  Sector  Program, 
Financial Sector Program I and Public Administration Reform Program Cluster in 2003; and the 
Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development and Financial Sector Program II in 2004). 
The PRSC III, which has an economy-wide reform agenda at the national level, complements 
these ADB assisted activities. 
       
24.  As a multisector instrument covering a range of issues related to poverty reduction, the 
PRSC  would  provide  ADB  with  an  opportunity  to  (i)  advance  policy  dialogue  in  a  well-
coordinated manner with other relevant ODA partners of Viet Nam, and (ii) ensure that key 
policy issues for implementation of ADB operations in Viet Nam are adequately considered and 
addressed in the policy dialogue between Government and the ODA community. The proposed 
program loan thus has strategic importance that would not ensue from sector-or subsector-
based program loans. 
 
25.  To  reduce  transaction  costs  for  the  Government  and  the  participating  development 
partners in a rather complex operation, the proposed loan pursues a program-based approach. 
This approach is in line with ADB’s recent move and practices toward adopting program-based 
and sector approaches in its lending operations to reduce transaction costs for its developing 
member countries as well as for its own operations. The approach is not only consistent with 
ADB’s reform agenda,13 Long-Term Strategic Framework, and Medium-Term Strategy, but also 
will directly help fulfill ADB’s obligations to the Rome Declaration on harmonizing procedures of 
multilateral development banks. 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
 A.  Objectives and Scope 
 
26.  The overall goal of the program loan is to help Viet Nam reduce poverty and sustain 
high-level economic growth, as envisaged in the CPRGS. The main purpose is to support the 
Government’s Poverty Reduction Program under the policy framework of the PRSC III, together  
                                                 
12 World Bank. 2004. Viet Nam Development Report 2004—Poverty. Poverty paper presented at the Consultative  
Group meeting, 2–3 December 2003. Hanoi. 
13  President Chino’s memo of 25 August 2004 entitled Today: Achieving Results Together.

8  
with other development partners, with a focus on reducing structural weaknesses, promoting 
socially inclusive development, and modernizing governance and public administration. To 
reduce poverty and sustain rapid economic growth, the program loan will strengthen Viet Nam’s 
reform program on three main fronts: 
 
(i)  Promote  growth  and  create  employment  by  increasing  internal  and  external 
competition, accelerating the divestiture of SOEs and SOCBs, and improving 
transparency and accountability in SOE operations, banking, and the financial 
sector.  
 
(ii)  Advance  human  development  by  increasing  the  budget  appropriation  for 
education and increase education standards; providing resources to cover the 
health care costs of the poor; developing mechanisms to complete the transfer of 
land-use rights to households, especially in upland and ethnic minority areas; 
and providing support measures to improve environmental and water resources 
management.  
 
(iii)  Increase transparency and accountability of public finances; promote simplified 
administrative procedures, and work to decrease corruption as part of a broader 
effort  to  build  modern  governance;  and  revamp  the  planning  processes  by 
moving away from a command approach to aligning policies and resources with 
the attainment of well-specified development goals based on empirical analysis 
and wider consultations.  
 B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
 
27.  Preparatory work to formulate the PRSC III, aiming to support the Government with 
CPRGS  implementation,  was  initiated  in  November  2003  with  the  participation  of  key 
development  assistance  partners  and  government  agencies.14  ADB  as  a  key  development 
partner was invited and participated in the preparation of the PRSC III, including in the policy 
discussions, program formulation, and program negotiations with the Government, even though 
ADB could not confirm if Special Funds resources would be available to allow cofinancing. SBV 
coordinated the overall processing of the PRSC III on behalf of the Government, while World 
Bank took the lead for the development partners (Appendix 2 provides summary details on the 
formulation of the program loan).  
 
28.  The policy framework of the PRSC III includes both deepening and broadening reforms 
under the three pillars: (i) transition to a market economy, (ii) social inclusion and environmental 
sustainability, and (iii) modern governance. Pillar I covers five sectors for policy reform actions: 
trade  integration,  SOE  reform,  financial  sector  reform,  private  sector  development,  and 
infrastructure. Pillar II includes sectors such as education, health, land, water, and environment. 
While pillar III focuses on sectors and activities related to improving governance, i.e., planning 
process, public financial management, financial accountability, public administration reform, and 
anticorruption. The policy matrix is presented in Appendix 4 and the development policy letter in 
Appendix 5. The achievement of prior actions as outlined in Appendix 4 is summarized in the 
following paragraphs. 
 
                                                 
14  Adapted from the jointly processed PRSC III report.

9
 
1.  Pillar I: Transition to a Market Economy  
29.  The  21  actions  relate  to  the  Government’s  work  to  reduce  inherent  structural 
weaknesses in trade, SOEs, and the financial sector; and improve the business environment. 15 
A key input for the negotiations for WTO accession is the preparation of detailed strategies for 
tariff  changes,  including  an  assessment  of  sector  impacts,  and  proposed  timing  for  their 
implementation.  But  more  importantly,  these  strategies  present  a  vision  for  the  long-term 
structure of protection. This is a vision where average tariffs are low, most nontariff barriers 
have  been  removed,  and  few  sectors  enjoy  high  protection  rates.  Several  policy  actions 
undertaken over the last year keep moving the economy in that direction. 
30.  Quantitative restrictions on the imports of petroleum products were removed. Under the 
PRSC III, tariffs on 484 items imported from the Peoples Republic of China, mostly agricultural 
and fisheries products, were lowered under the Early Harvest Program, which was a step 
toward  implementation  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations-China  Free  Trade 
Agreement. Separately, several regulations were made WTO compliant last year. They refer to 
customs valuation and to the application of the harmonized classification and coding system on 
a multilateral basis. 
31.  Transformation  of  SOE  ownership  has  been  a  major  policy  reform  area  under  the 
previous PRSCs. Under the PRSC I, improvements in the overall framework for enterprise 
divestiture,  including  the  setup  of  a  social  safety  net  for  redundant  SOE  workers,  were 
satisfactorily completed. This allowed the meeting of cautious targets for enterprise divestiture 
by the end of the PRSC I. Since then the number of SOEs included in officially approved plans 
for transformation has increased substantially. The program supported from the PRSC II onward 
is  based  on  a  series  of  104  SOE  reform  plans  prepared  by  line  ministries,  provincial 
governments, and government corporations. Unlike previous blueprints for SOE reform, these 
plans, which identify the SOEs to be divested by name and indicate a specific year for the 
ownership transformation to be carried out, are in the public domain. The overall aim is to 
equitize, sell, or liquidate around 2,400 SOEs, employing roughly 0.4 million workers, over 3 
years. 
32.  Progress in the planned SOE transformations is being monitored with monthly reporting 
on the number and names of the concerned SOEs. The monitoring scheme also puts under 
surveillance the creation of new SOEs, and of joint-stock companies involving SOEs. Timely 
implementation of ownership transformations under the new SOE reform plans was considered 
a trigger for the PRSC III. According to the National Steering Committee for Enterprise Reform 
and Development, 814 SOEs were transformed in 2003. This includes 649 SOE transformations 
approved under the 104 reform plans and 165 approved prior to the 104 restructuring plans. 
The  corresponding  figures  are  somewhat  smaller  if  transformations  are  only  considered 
complete after the first shareholders meeting is held and the enterprise is registered. But the 
average lead time between transaction approval and business registration has remained fairly 
constant at around 90 days over the past 3 years. By either measure, 2003 was by far the best 
year in terms of numbers of SOEs transformed: a 95% increase over 2002 as measured by the 
National Steering Committee for Enterprise Reform and Development, and a 60% increase in 
                                                 
15 ADB is supporting nonbanking financial sector development and small and medium enterprise development 
through program loans and technical assistance. The World Bank is supporting public financial management 
reform through a separate credit.

10  
terms of business registrations. Figures for the first 4 months of 2004 confirm the acceleration in 
the transformation of ownership. Admittedly, actual transformations fall short of the targets set in 
the 104 reform plans. But this is partly due to slippages in approval of the plans, which took 
place only by mid-2003. 
33.  So far, the reform of large SOEs, including government corporations, has focused on 
making them more competitive. However, the 9th Plenum of the 9th Party Congress approved 
the equitization of large SOEs. The subsectors likely to be covered include electricity, post and 
telecommunications, chemicals, metallurgy, banking, and insurance. Shares in these entities 
could be sold to outsiders and the valuations of the enterprises should be based on market 
values. In March 2004, the Ministry of Planning and Investment identified the legal documents to 
be promulgated, amended, or supplemented to prepare for transformation of the larger SOEs, 
as well as speed up equitization of smaller ones. In parallel, guidelines for the operation of the 
central Debts and Assets Trading Company have been issued. The Debts and Assets Trading 
Company  was  set  up on  a  pilot basis  under  the  PRSC  II  due  to  the  lack  of appropriate 
mechanisms  for  nonperforming  loan  resolution.  While  SOCBs  have  their  own  asset 
management companies, they currently lack the power to reach foreclosure, seize assets, and 
force  enterprise  liquidation  if  necessary.  The  Debts  and  Assets  Trading  Company,  with  a 
planned chartered capital of D2 trillion, is to be operated on a pilot basis first, covering 20 SOEs 
with bad debts amounting to about D1.5 trillion. Of these 20 SOEs, 12 will be equitized, 6 will be 
transformed into one-member limited liability companies, one will pass on to the ownership of its 
workers, and one is to be merged. 
34.  Progress has been slower with monitoring of SOE performance. In the past, few SOEs 
complied  with  existing  reporting  obligations.  Decision  271/2003/QD-TTg,  issued  under  the 
PRSC  II,  establishes  administrative  sanctions  for  lack  of  compliance  and  instructs  the 
classification of SOEs in one of three categories depending on their earnings, returns on state 
equity, and ability to service their debts. Actual classification is expected to start in late 2004. 
Enterprises that are classified as bad performers for 2 years in a row are in principle subject to 
reorganization, including changes in management. SOEs that do not submit their financial 
reports in a timely manner can be fined. These sanctions on delayed reporting will in turn serve 
as a basis to evaluate and classify SOE performance. 
35.  Banking reform has been the main focus of financial sector reform. A plan was issued for 
the international integration of banking and SBV reform, in light of WTO accession. The plan 
seeks to amend, supplement, revise, and eliminate legal documents and policies unsuitable for 
international  integration  commitments.  It  envisages  actions  to  strengthen  the  supervisory 
capacity of SBV, and move the supervision of banks closer to international practices, including 
the implementation of a rating system based on capital assets management, earnings, and 
liquidity. It also foresees the completion of modern payment and financial information systems in 
the sector. In parallel, the four largest SOCBs have developed new credit manuals, which will 
provide the banks with the critical foundation to improve credit and overall risk management 
upon implementation 
36.  Other policy actions in this area aim at increasing transparency and accountability. A 
new  chart  of  accounts  for  banks  was  adopted  in  early  2004.  This  new  chart,  and  new 
regulations on accounting and bank reporting policies are close to international accounting 
standards. A 60-day limit was imposed on the negotiation of international accounting standards 
audit by the SOCBs. The four largest SOCBs have been subjected to international accounting 
standards since the PRSC I. However, release of the audits has sometimes been delayed, by 
more than 9 months because of negotiations with SOCBs on the qualifications of the audits.

11
37.  Equally significant are the plans to equitize two SOCBs, with a strategic investor for one 
of them. The Government had already announced its intention to equitize the smallest SOCB, 
Mekong Housing Bank, under PRSC II. This equitization is scheduled to take place by 2005 and 
will involve the participation of an international strategic investor. More recently, the Prime 
Minister’s Directive No. 11/2004/CT-TTg, on the acceleration of SOE restructuring, also directed 
SBV, in coordination with the Ministry of Finance (MOF), to submit draft equitization plans for 
the Viet Nam Commercial Bank for Foreign Trade and Mekong Housing Bank. The Viet Nam 
Commercial Bank for Foreign Trade is one of the largest and most profitable SOCBs. Whether 
the  equitization  will  aim  at  raising  capital  only,  or  will  also  serve  to  strengthen  corporate 
governance, remains to be seen. 
38.  Policy  (i.e.,  directed)  lending  was  formally  separated  from  the  commercial  banking 
system  under  the  PRSC  I,  but  it  continued  to  grow  at  a  rapid  pace.  The  Development 
Assistance Fund expanded considerably over the last 3 years and remains a significant vehicle 
for  routing  financial  support  to  SOEs.  The  issuance  of  Decree  106/2004/ND-CP,  which 
regulates the operation of the Development Assistance Fund, is an important step toward 
providing a sound regulatory framework for such policy lending. The decree states that only 
projects that are capable of direct repayment, have socioeconomic efficiency, and have feasible 
business  or  production  plans,  are  eligible  for  Development  Assistance  Fund  support.  The 
decree also stresses that project assets are to be used as security, and those assets cannot be 
assigned, disposed, mortgaged, or pledged until loans are fully repaid. An element of risk-
sharing, through copayments by other government bodies or by commercial banks, is also built 
into the decree.  
39.  Steps have been taken over the last year to boost the nascent securities market. In 
November  2003  the  Government  issued  Decree  144/2003/ND-CP,  easing  the  listing 
requirements for firms. The minimum capitalization requirement for firms was halved to D5 
billion. Joint-stocks banks with a charter capital of D70 billion or more, at least 5 years in 
operation, 2 consecutive years of profits in the last 2 years, and a nonperforming loan ratio 
below 3%, can be listed as well. A new regulatory framework for security investment funds was 
approved, and in March 2004 the Viet Nam State Securities Commission licensed the first of 
those funds, creating a new investment channel for both domestic and foreign investors. 
40.  Reforms related to private sector development aim to build the legal foundations of a 
market economy and ensure equitable opportunities. The unification of the corporate tax rate, 
irrespective of ownership, was one move toward the equal treatment of enterprises regardless 
of their institutional nature. The new tax rate of 28% lowered the tax rate on domestic private 
enterprises  from  32%  and  increased  the  tax  rate  previously  levied  on  foreign  invested 
enterprises from 25%. At the same time the supplementary income tax for domestic enterprises 
was eliminated, along with the profit remittance tax for foreign invested enterprises. The policy 
of phasing out dual pricing for public utilities is another welcome move in this direction. Under 
Decree 164, tax incentives to foreign and local companies were harmonized. The strengthening 
of the administration of intellectual property rights substantially shortens the processing time 
from application to actual registration or rejection. 
41.  A new legal framework for the organization, operation, and management of associations 
was adopted in 2003. Decree 88/2003/ND-CP signals the Government’s stronger interest in the 
role  and  development  of  business  associations.  While  Decree  88  provides  a  more 
comprehensive and transparent legal framework, it may not be well suited to the needs of all 
nongovernment organizations. Consultation and legislative work may be needed in this area.

12  
42.  In  infrastructure,  the  expansion  of  the  CPRGS  to  include  large-scale  infrastructure 
represents a change in the Government’s approach to public investment. In the past, the public 
investment program was a compilation of projects by line ministries, provinces, and SOEs, 
without much screening or overall coherence. While feasibility studies were conducted in the 
case of large projects, no assessment was made of benefits and costs, growth, or poverty 
reduction impacts. The separation between capital and recurrent expenditures usually resulted in 
poor maintenance. Environmental impacts were not systematically conducted, the handling of 
resettlement was controversial at times, project management raised considerable fiduciary risks, 
and community participation and supervision was limited in the case of local projects. The new 
chapter on large-scale infrastructure, added to the CPRGS in 2003, is expected to serve as the 
basis for a gradual strengthening of the institutional mechanisms supporting public investment. 
 
43.  An encouraging shift to modern regulation of competition and pricing policies is occurring 
in telecommunications. For infrastructure services, the Government needs to move from a 
model  with  a  single  public  provider,  sometimes  leading  to  high  user  costs,  to  a  modern 
regulation of competition and pricing. The regulation of sectors with network externalities is 
bound to raise difficult policy trade-offs between efficiency and coverage across a variety of 
subsectors (power, water and sanitation, and telecommunications). To some extent, this is a 
new area in policy reform, barely addressed by the CPRGS. However, over the last year 
encouraging signs have been taken to move away from the monopoly model, especially in 
telecommunications. Internet service provision was opened by licensing new entrants. In mobile 
telephone,  competitive  entry  by  a  new  mobile  operator  was  authorized.  And  staged  price 
reductions  were  implemented  for  these  services.  As  of  January  2004,  telecommunications 
prices in Viet Nam are in line with regional levels. 
2.  Pillar II: Social Inclusion and Environmental Sustainability 
44.  Issues relate to social inclusion and environmental sustainability, particularly education, 
health, water, and environment. For education, progress is needed to increase overall spending, 
improve resource allocation, and improve the quality of teaching. The overall approach in this 
area  is captured  by  the  Education  for  All  framework  approved  by  the  Prime  Minister  and 
adopted under the PRSC II. Measures adopted over the last year hinge on the combination of 
two elements: quality standards and resource allocation mechanisms. The expenditure share of 
education and training was increased to 17.1% of the budget for 2004, which is close to the 
18% CPRGS target for 2005. This share was 13.8% in 2002, and increased to 15.8% in 2003. 
In parallel, national minimum standards for primary schools were adopted. A survey covering all 
districts has been launched to assess the current situation relative to the standards, which refer 
to  physical  infrastructure,  teaching  staff,  school  organization  and  management,  social 
participation  in  education,  educational  activities  and  quality,  and  expected  educational 
outcomes. 
45.  This overall approach to Education for All is to be complemented by a targeting strategy. 
An index of educational disadvantage has already been developed, combining net enrollment 
rates, the percentage of 6-year-old children having access to schooling, and completion rates. 
This targeting mechanism allows identification of a substantial number of districts with indices 
well below the national average. A fundamental upgrade in management practices is expected 
with future PRSCs, subsequent to the piloting of a medium-term expenditure framework for the 
education sector working with the Ministry of Education and Training.

13
46.  To redress the imbalances in health outcomes, the reform program focuses on changing 
the financing of health. An important policy action under the PRSC II was the adoption of 
Decision 139/2002/QD-TTg, which made more funding available for health services for the poor 
at  the  provincial  level.  Health  care  funds  for  the  poor  are  to  receive  sufficient  funding  to 
reimburse outlays of D70,000 per poor beneficiary per year, with 75% of this amount provided 
by the central Government and the remaining 25% covered through community and individual 
contributions.  In  January  2004  the  Government  assessment  of  the  first  year  of  program 
implementation  identified  important  achievements  as  well  as  obstacles  encountered  in 
implementation. As an indicator of progress, all provinces and cities directly under the central 
Government have set up health care funds for the poor and established fund management 
committees. Initial estimates place the number of target beneficiaries at 14.6 million. Nearly 
37%  of  the  target  beneficiaries  are  located  in  the  northern  mountains  region.  The  central 
Government’s portion to the health care funds for the poor has been paid in full. While Decision 
139 has increased the flow of government health funding to the poor, some problems remain. 
These include the provinces’ preference for directly reimbursing providers instead of purchasing 
health insurance cards, inadequate funding provided per beneficiary, and absence of additional 
financial  support  to  facilities  to  cover  the  unreimbursed  cost  of  providing  services  to 
beneficiaries.  Other  issues  relate  to  the  slow  pace  of  identifying  eligible  beneficiaries  and 
extending partial benefits to near poor households. All of these issues point to the need to 
closely follow up on the implementation of this crucial reform. 
47.  A national steering committee on the prevention of AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency 
syndrome), drug use, and prostitution was recently established by the Prime Minister. A policy 
framework for HIV (human immunodeficiency virus)/AIDS is being developed to identify critical 
needs,  challenges,  and  opportunities.  Of  importance,  future  HIV/AIDS  prevention  agenda 
should  link  HIV/AIDS  to  other  social  and  economic  development  plans,  increase  the 
Government’s human resource capacity and financial commitment to HIV/AIDS, and broaden 
implementation of successful pilot programs. More broadly, HIV/AIDS need to be recognized as 
a gender issue and the approach to HIV/AIDS needs to become a program of harm prevention, 
rather than elimination of a social evil. Under the PRSC III, the national steering committee 
issued a draft 10-year strategy for slowing and halting the spread of HIV/AIDS (approved by the 
Prime Minister in December 2003). The adoption of a set of action plans to implement the 
strategy is an important signal of the Governments’ recognition of the need for decisive action in 
the face of the emerging AIDS epidemic in Viet Nam. The action program includes steps to 
remove  the  stigma  around  those  who  are  HIV-positive  and  resolve  policy  inconsistencies 
between the public health approach and the social evils approach. Dissemination of information 
and provision of adequate and affordable care and treatment are key components of the plan. 
48.  The new Land Law, passed in late 2003 and brought into effect in July 2004, supports 
access to land for all sectors, addresses land-tenure security, recognizes community land-use 
practices, and develops a unified land administration system. While some of the specifics will 
depend on implementing decrees, circulars, and decisions currently under preparation, the new 
Land Law in itself represents an important step forward. The law specifies that all land use 
certificates must bear the names of both spouses, thereby filling a gap of the older version. The 
law also expands into areas such as the subleasing land, and the use of land use certificates as 
capital contributions for joint ventures. It stipulates that the valuation of land for purposes such 
as taxation, registration, or payment of compensation should be in line with market prices. 
Investors  operating  under  the  Foreign  Investment  Law  will  still  need  to  acquire  land  use 
certificates by leasing them from the state. However, those who pay the entire amount of rent in 
a single lump sum up-front are allowed to sublease, assign, or sell their land use certificates 
during the lease term. Paying the rent as a lump sum thus gives foreign land users similar rights

14  
as domestic land users. The issuance of land use certificates has been decentralized to district 
and provincial governments, and a unified system of land administration agencies will be set up. 
In addition, more transparent mechanisms for resolving land disputes have been promulgated 
with a greater role for people’s courts.  
49.  The Government is also strengthening the process of allocating upland to local people 
and local communities. Many among the poor depend on upland, including forestland, for their 
livelihood. The Government issued resolution 28/NQ/TW to accelerate restructuring of state 
forestry enterprises. This resolution promotes the allocation of underutilized land and forest 
currently  under  the  control  of  state  forestry  enterprises  to  the  local  population,  local 
communities,  or  private  enterprises.  Further,  the  revised  Law  on  Forest  Protection  and 
Development, submitted to the National Assembly in May 2004, provides the overall framework 
for the move to more social and community-based forestry. For the first time, it recognizes the 
forest use right of households, communities, and other sectors, as well as their ownership of 
plantation forests. And it proposes assigning an economic value to each forest production area 
as the basis for their allocation or lease to forest managers. In parallel, key stakeholders have 
also started the consultation process to revise the forest sector development strategy, which is 
expected to produce a long-term, broad, positive impact not only on poverty reduction but also 
on sustainable management of forest, land, water, and environment in upland areas. 
50.  In the water resources sector, an important policy action undertaken over the last year is 
the  involvement  of  users  in  irrigation  management.  Decree  143/2003/ND-CP  transfers  the 
management of small-scale, stand-alone irrigation systems, as well as tertiary and secondary 
canals, to cooperatives or groups of water users. Irrigation services, which were until recently 
under the control of state-owned irrigation management companies, will thus become more 
responsive to the needs of local populations. The critical role of improving the quality of irrigation 
services to intensifying and diversifying agriculture is recognized and is among the main drivers 
of agricultural growth and poverty reduction in rural areas.  
 
51.  Environmental safeguards for public investments need to be improved and the polluter 
pays principle introduced. Environmental impact assessments of public investment projects have 
been delegated to several provincial governments, particularly in the regions that are currently 
driving economic growth, such as Binh Duong, Da Nang, Hanoi, and Ho Chi Minh City. The 
environmental impact assessment capacity of these local governments has been considerably 
strengthened,  in  parallel  with  increasing  their  empowerment  to  make  investment  decisions. 
Amendments to the regulations guiding implementation of the Law on Environment Protection 
were  recently  submitted  to  the  Government  for  approval.  These  amendments,  based  on 
consultations  held  in  2003,  aim  at  further  decentralizing  environmental  impact  assessment 
responsibilities. The control of pollution by existing firms was strengthened. Polluter pays fees on 
industrial  and  municipal  wastewater  discharges  were  introduced  by  67/2003/ND-CP  and 
multiministerial  circular  125/2003/TT-LB  BTC-BTNMT.  These  fees  apply  to  all  discharges 
independently from enterprise ownership. Decree 64/2003/QD-TTg requires establishments that 
cause serious environmental pollution to either upgrade their technology or move to authorized 
zones. Noncompliant establishments are to be closed. Equally important, Decree 109/2003/ND-
CP promulgates the conservation and sustainable use of wetlands. It regulates detrimental 
human activity in wetland areas, while taking into account sustainability of the livelihoods of the 
rural poor.

15
  3.  Pillar III: Modern Governance 
52.  The focus is on improving the planning process, public financial management, delivery of 
public administration services to people and businesses, and anticorruption initiatives. The 
CPRGS approach is increasingly being incorporated into provincial planning. Due to increased 
decentralization, resources from the central budget only represent a fraction (sometimes minor) 
of total local public expenditure. While the CPRGS sets national objectives, provincial policy 
making  needs  to  take  into  account  the  local  dimensions  of  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. Such alignment of planning processes to localized development targets is still new to 
many local officials, who are not fully used to the idea of setting development targets based on 
evidence  and  consultation,  gearing  policies  to  attain  those  targets,  aligning  resources 
accordingly, and monitoring the results. During the last year, however, incorporation of the 
CPRGS approach in provincial planning has progressed. The process has involved three main 
activities: (i) regional workshops to discuss the approach and its implications for sector and local 
planning  processes,  (ii)  regional  poverty  assessments  focusing  on  specific  dimensions  of 
poverty in each region, and (iii) support by development agencies to 19 pilot provinces to 
integrate the CPRGS process into local and sector planning. Crucially, the Ministry of Planning 
and  Investment  has  issued  guidelines  to  prepare  provincial  5-year  and  annual  plans  that 
incorporate the CPRGS approach.  
53.  The trend to increased decentralization, with the associated reliance on local fees and 
out-of-pocket payments, makes the allocation of resources key to improving service delivery. A 
plan was to develop medium-term expenditure frameworks in sectors that play a direct role in 
reducing  poverty  and  keeping  development  inclusive:  education,  health,  agriculture,  and 
transport. The expenditure frameworks are part of a broader effort to improve transparency and 
efficiency in budget management. They should lead to better integration of capital and current 
expenditures, with a forward-looking perspective. The Ministry of Education and Training has 
been selected to pilot a shadow medium-term expenditure framework, with improved accounting 
systems and control procedures by MOF. Once implemented, this expenditure framework is 
expected to lead to a fundamental upgrade of management practices. 
54.   The implementation of the revised Law on the State Budget is one of the cornerstones of 
the  public  financial  management  reform  program.  It  (i)  clearly  delineates  the  roles  of  the 
National Assembly and the provincial people’s councils in budget approval, (ii) streamlines the 
budget execution processes, and (iii) assigns the Treasury Department as the lead agency 
responsible  for  budget  execution  and  financial  management  information.  Currently  three 
separate accounting systems are in use for the State Budget Department, the State Treasury 
Department, and spending units. Extrabudgetary funds, onlent ODA, and much commune-level 
spending are currently not consolidated into the budget or recorded in the State Treasury 
Department's main accounting system. The lack of a fully consolidated and integrated budget 
makes  monitoring  total  revenues  and  expenditures,  assessing  how  resources  are  being 
allocated, and comparing plans with outputs difficult. One step undertaken last year toward 
implementing the new Budget Law was the unification of the accounting systems of the State 
Budget and the State Treasury. 
55.  The  design  of  an  overall  treasury  and  budget  management  information  system  is 
complete. The system is based on modern principles of public financial management, such as 
the World Bank-International Monetary Fund Treasury Reference Model. The new system will 
replace the current systems that are fragmented technologically and have overlapping and 
conflicting functionality. Implementing the treasury and budget management information system 
should lead to a vast improvement in the integrity in overall fiscal data, transparency, and

16  
control  at  all  levels  of  government.  A  decree  has  also  been  submitted  on  implementing 
accounting standards set by the new Accounting Law using spending units based on state 
budget resources. 
56.  Viet Nam has made significant progress in laying the foundation for public and private 
financial accountability in recent years. To strengthen legislative oversight of public accounts, a 
legal mandate was issued for the State Audit of Viet Nam to operate outside of the executive 
branch of Government and report its audit results to the National Assembly on a routine basis. 
The new Accounting Law was issued in accordance with international practice. Since then, 16 
accounting standards and 27 auditing standards have been issued.  
57.  A  new  decree  to  guide  implementation  of  the  Law  on  the  Promulgation  of  Legal 
Normative Documents supports further legal development. The decree stipulates that the legal 
normative documents should be published for at least a couple weeks in the Official Gazette for 
them to become effective. While the requirement to publish in the Official Gazette is made in the 
law,  the  implications  of  nonpublication  were  not  explicit.  Also,  this  new  decree  sets  clear 
guidelines for the collection of comments from stakeholders directly affected by legal normative 
documents. A minimum period of 20 working days is stipulated for consultation, which can take 
place through mass media or the Internet.  
58.   The Government’s decision to replicate the one-stop shop model nationwide is an 
important  step  in  public  administration  reform.  The  Public  Administration  Reform  Master 
Program 2001–2010 represents an ambitious policy agenda aiming to make the civil service 
more responsive, transparent, efficient, and accountable.16 As a first step, a plan for simplifying 
administrative  procedures  was  adopted.  The  one-stop  shop  model  was  promulgated  as  a 
national policy under the PRSC III, through the issuance of Decision 181. The model aims to 
provide a clear, accessible, and recognizable entry point for people in need of administrative 
services;  increase  transparency  on  fees  and  procedures;  improve  service  quality;  and 
streamline procedures. As of 1 January 2004, the one-stop shop model had been implemented 
in 35 of 64 provinces, 483 of 654 districts, and 695 of 10,709 communes. Subsequent PRSCs 
will monitor implementation in terms of both quantity (the number of units implementing one-
stop shop) and quality. 
59.  Over the last year openness to feedback by users of public services has improved 
considerably. To enhance delivery, the Ministry of Home Affairs supported a report card survey 
on a pilot basis in four urban localities (Da Nang, Haiphong, Ho Chi Minh City, and Nam Dinh) 
These signal a stronger focus on performance management and service delivery outcome. The 
report card survey is expected to enhance transparency and accountability, generate user 
feedback on specific services, facilitate comparisons across units, and foster a dialogue on 
practical problem-solving in service delivery. A series of participatory poverty assessments, 
including questions on governance, were conducted in 12 provinces during July-August 2003. 
60.   The  process  of  successfully  moving  to  a  rules-based  market  economy  requires 
strengthening institutions and developing mechanisms for accountability, thereby reducing the 
scope for corruption. At present, the understanding of corruption in Viet Nam is predominantly 
based  on  anecdotal  evidence.  To  address  this,  the  Government  has  recently  launched  a 
diagnostic study of corruption. The study results will feed into an amendment of the Ordinance 
                                                 
16 ADB is supporting implementation of training, retraining, and computerization of state administration components 
of the Government’s master program for public administration reform under loan-No 1992- Support to the 
Implementation of Public Administration Reform Master Program Phase I, approved in 2003.

17
against Corruption. The Government has signaled its serious intent to tackle corruption.17 It has 
strengthened  the  State  Inspectorate  to  enforce  laws  and  regulations  related  to  public 
investment. A draft ordinance to strengthen the public procurement process was issued. Public 
procurement  is  an  important  part  of  the  Government’s  ongoing  efforts  to  improve  public 
expenditure management. The ordinance makes open bidding the main method of procurement, 
mandates standard bidding documents, and introduces the pass-fail system as an alternative to 
the  merit  points  system.  To  enhance  transparency  in  the  public  procurement  process  the 
ordinance mandates a procurement bulletin, to be published on paper and electronically. It also 
strengthens provisions related to inspections and handling of violations. 
 
C.  Important Features 
 
61.  A social and poverty impact assessment was undertaken in relation to the program loan 
(a  summary  is  in  Appendix  6,  and  additional  details  in  Supplementary  Appendix  A).  The 
assessment concludes that the activities will have no adverse impacts on indigenous people or 
have gender implications. The loan will not involve land acquisition and/or resettlement.  
 
62.  An environmental assessment of the potential environmental impacts associated with 
the program loan policy matrix is available in Supplementary Appendix B. The assessment 
reveals that most policy reforms will produce positive impacts on urban and rural environments. 
Most of the reforms aim to improve governance, accountability, and transparency. While not 
specifically designed for environmental protection, these reforms tend to promote optimal and 
efficient use of resources, including natural resources. Some of the reforms aim to improve 
environmental protection and management, while others aim to improve health and education, 
which tend to have indirect positive impacts on environmental sustainability. These reforms fit 
well with Viet Nam’s environmental policy needs, and are therefore considered practical and 
necessary next steps for the country’s environmental management framework.  
 
63.  Some  policy  reforms  will  likely  have  no  impact  on  the  environment.  These  include 
reforms of public financial management, private sector development, and the financial sector. 
These reforms could have a positive trickle-down effect, but the links between such impacts are 
sufficiently subtle that they cannot easily be evaluated or monitored. The remaining policy 
reforms such as SOE reforms and reforms to move to a market economy have a mix of positive 
impacts  or  no  impacts.  However,  most  have  the  potential  to  support  prudent  use  of 
environmental  resources,  which  can  be  realized  if  each  reform  is  designed  with  due 
consideration to their environmental implications.  
 
D.  Financing Plan 
   
64.  The Government’s estimation of the financing gap for 2004 is US$3.3 billion.18 ODA and 
foreign direct investment inflows are expected to meet the financing gap. The Government 
estimate for financing requirements for key CPRGS activities amounts to about US$800 million. 
The resolution of nonperforming loans is estimated to cost about US$2 billion in total. The 
estimated costs of some specific CPRGS programs for 2004 are (i) health funds for the poor— 
about US$50 million; and (ii) increase in spending on education from 15.8 % to 17.3 % of the 
government budget—about US$20 million.  
 
                                                 
17  Viet  Nam  also  endorsed  the  ADB-Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  Initiative  for 
Anticorruption in Asia and Pacific in July 2004. 
18  Based on information provided by the Government during PRSC III processing.

18  
65.  ODA resources for 2004 are expected to fund about US$178 million. The World Bank 
has already approved a US$100 million International Development Association credit to support 
the  PRSC  III19,  and  other  development  partners  are  providing  cofinancing,  including  the 
Canadian International Development Agency (Can$6.3 million grant),20 Denmark (US$10 million 
grant),  the  European  Commission  (€15  million  grant),  the  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation (US$18 million equivalent loan), Netherlands (€4 million grant), and the United 
Kingdom’s Department for International Development (₤20 million grant). 
 
66.  The Government has requested a loan of US$6.4 million from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources as ADB’s support to the implementation of the CPRGS following the policy framework 
of the PRSC III program. The program loan would contribute to financing the cost of adjustment 
resulting from implementation of the policy matrix, particularly the prior actions for the PRSC III, 
and to supporting and facilitating the Government’s continued and deepened reform program for 
poverty reduction. The loan will be disbursed upon declaration of loan effectiveness. 
 
67.  The loan will have a 24-year term including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 
1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms 
and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The Government has provided ADB with (i) 
the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s Special Funds resources on the basis of 
these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
68.  The loan proceeds may be used to finance eligible imports incurred within 180 days prior 
to the date of loan effectiveness. The loan closing date will be 31 December 2005. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Program Management 
 
69.  SBV will be the Executing Agency. The program is being implemented through 20 line 
ministries and government agencies in accordance with Paragraph 3 of Schedule V in the Loan 
Agreement. 
 
70.  The National Steering Committee for implementation of the CPRGS and PRSCs was 
established in 2002. It is chaired by a first deputy prime minister, and consists of heads of 20 
relevant line ministries. SBV is assigned as the agency responsible, in close collaboration with 
the World Bank, for preparing and implementing the PRSCs. A deputy governor of SBV acts as 
National  Steering  Committee’s  standing  vice  chair.  This  quasi-advisory  body  has  several 
representatives from key economic ministries, such as the ministries of agriculture and rural 
development; education and training; finance; justice; labor, invalids, and social affairs; and 
transport; as well as the Office of the Government, Party's Economic Commission, and SBV 
representing the policy reform areas under PRSC III and subsequent PRSCs.  
 
71.  An  interministerial  working  group  and  a  secretariat  to  implement  and  monitor  the 
CPRGS have been established at the Ministry of Planning and Investment. The working group 
comprises representatives from key economic ministries, including those represented on the 
National Steering Committee representing the respective policy reform areas under the PRSC 
III. Among the goals of the Interministerial Working Group is the implementation of the CPRGS

19
at  subnational  levels.  The  CPRGS  Secretariat  at  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment 
supports provincial governments in adapting the CPRGS to their own context, and reformulating 
plans and budgets accordingly. At present, 19 provinces are going through this process, with 
financial support from development agencies. The CPRGS Secretariat prepared the first annual 
progress report on CPRGS implementation under the guidance of the Interministerial Working 
Group. 
 
72. In addition, given the intensive and complex coordination required to manage this very 
comprehensive reform program, SBV will be strengthening program implementation, particularly 
results monitoring and reporting and public discussion and awareness. 
 
2.  Period of Implementation 
 
73.  The program period will be from 30 June 2004 to 31 December 2005. 
 
3.  Procurement and Disbursement 
 
74.  The proceeds of the loan will be utilized in accordance with the simplified disbursement 
procedures and related requirements for program loans, goods and services produced and 
originating in ADB member countries will be procured, with due consideration for economy and 
efficiency, in accordance with standard public procedures in Viet Nam, and normal private 
sector commercial practices, acceptable to ADB. Goods commonly traded on the international 
commodity markets will be procured in accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade and 
acceptable to ADB. 
 
75.  The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche, contingent upon loan effectiveness. The 
proceeds of the loan will be disbursed for a broad range of imports, subject to a negative list of 
ineligible items (Appendix 7). Loan proceeds will be disbursed on the basis of a certification 
provided by the Government the value of total imports minus (i) imports from nonmember 
countries, (ii) ineligible imports, and (iii) imports financed under other ODA, is equal to or greater 
than the amount expected to be disbursed during the year. 
 
4.  Counterpart Funds 
 
76.  The counterpart funds to be generated from the loan proceeds will be used to finance 
the  adjustment  costs  of  implementation  of  the  reform  program  as  per  the  policy  matrix 
(Appendix 4). 
 
5.  Monitoring  
 
77.  Viet Nam continues to make good use of information and analysis in its policy making 
and development of individual components of the PRSC program. PRSC III continues to build 
on this experience, streamlining the numerous ongoing monitoring and evaluation initiatives. 
Key sources of monitoring information for poverty and program outcomes include the proposed 
biannual  household  living  standard  survey,  periodic  participatory  poverty  assessments,  the 
small business registration survey, public expenditure tracking survey, as well as the quarterly 
progress reports from the relevant sector ministries and committees implementing the reform 
program.  
 
78  In addition, the strengthening of management information systems for SOEs and for all 
public spending, both led by MOF, is an integral part of the PRSC program. Efforts for provincial

20  
implementation of the CPRGS rely on the development of appropriate monitoring indicators as 
well. Gradually, the number of indicators has been narrowed to around 40, roughly 100 less 
than when the process started. Many of the indicators in this narrower set will be generated 
using the new household living standard surveys.  
 
  6.  Reporting 
 
79.  The Government will prepare and provide semi-annual progress reports on the program 
loan. ADB will participate in all joint assessments by the Government and development partners 
on the outcomes of the PRSC III and PRSC IV triggers (measures and actions). Further details 
are presented the program framework in Appendix 1. 
 
 
V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
80.  Policy reform actions will improve transparency and accountability in SOE operations 
and in the banking subsector. The establishment of a sound regulatory framework for policy 
resulting in increased private investment and exports will lead to additional job creation. The 
program  loan  will  promote  human  development  by  improving  access  by  poor  people  to 
education and health care, and increasing the security of asset ownership in the form of a new 
land law. The policy reform under the PRSC III will increase transparency and accountability of 
public finances and improve legal transparency and accessibility, by laying the foundations for a 
state  ruled  by  law,  and  by  addressing  a  number  of  gaps  in  the  Budget  Law.  Further 
decentralization  of  public  administration  leading  to  better  service  delivery  to  the  poor  and 
increased local beneficiary participation are other expected benefits. Development outcomes 
are summarized in Appendix 8. 
   
81.  Through appropriate measures and proactive programs, the Government will need to 
mitigate the potential adverse economic, social, and environmental impacts of increasing trade 
openness, reducing the number of state enterprises, and liberalizing land transactions.  
 
82.  Incomplete structural reform could jeopardize growth and stability in the longer term. 
Haphazard  introduction  of  market  forces  in  the  social  sectors,  and  the  trend  toward 
decentralization have put service delivery under strain. At the same time, fast integration with 
the world economy may lead to increased inequality, at least temporarily, as the benefits accrue 
to specific regions and skills disproportionately. Growth in Viet Nam could become less inclusive 
in the years to come. 
 
83.  A  fiduciary  risk  is  associated  with  the  PRSC  III,  if  progress  on  enhancing  budget 
transparency and tackling corruption is inadequate. The Government is indicating new resolve 
to address these issues. It has recently embarked on revamping its anticorruption strategy. It 
has also enhanced budget transparency. Their full implementation will be crucial to mitigate the 
fiduciary risk. 
 
VI.  ASSURANCES 
 
84.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents:

21
(i)  The measures and actions included in the Support to Implementation of Poverty 
Reduction Program and specified in the development policy letter and the policy 
matrix will be adopted in a timely manner. 
 
(ii)  Such measures and actions will continue to be in effect for the duration of the 
Support to Implementation of Poverty Reduction Program under the CPRGS and 
PRSC frameworks. 
 
(iii)  Adequate and timely counterpart funds will be provided for the implementation of 
the Poverty Reduction Program under the PRSC III. 
 
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
85.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 4,346,000 to the 
Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Support to Implementation of Poverty Reduction Program 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 24 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  The Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy  
 
1.  Evolution of the Strategy 
 
1.  The Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS) is the outcome of 
extensive  discussions,  stakeholder  consultations,  and  review  work  undertaken  by  the 
Government, working closely with development agencies through the Poverty Task Force. The 
formulation of the CPRGS was coordinated by the CPRGS Secretariat based in the Ministry of 
Planning  and  Investment  and  supported  by  several  official  development  assistance  (ODA) 
partners, including the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
2.  The CPRGS, approved by the Prime Minister in May 2002, translated the vision of a 
market  economy  with  a  socialist  orientation  presented  in  the  10-Year  Socioeconomic 
Development  Strategy  for  2001–2010  into  concrete  public  actions.  Unlike  previous  planning 
documents,  the  CPRGS  is  focused  and  clearly  defines  development  targets,  identifies 
appropriate policies to attain those targets, and aligns resources to those policies. The country’s 
development goals, which are a local version of the Millennium Development Goals, are among 
the key targets pursued in the CPRGS (Table A2). In 2003, the CPRGS was expanded, with a 
thorough  discussion  of  the  role  of  large  infrastructure  in  promoting  economic  and  social 
development. 
 
3.  The CPRGS provides a framework for poverty reduction policies, programs, and actions in 
Viet  Nam  (Figure  A2.1).  The  ODA  community  has  adopted  the  CPRGS  as  the  reference 
document for planning and formulating external assistance.

2.  Implementation and Monitoring  
 
4.  Formulation of policy reforms and programs under the CPRGS involves many ministries 
and is coordinated by the National Steering Committee. The committee is chaired by a first 
deputy  prime  minister  and  comprises  the  top  officials  of  20  relevant  line  ministries.  An 
interministerial working group and secretariat to implement and monitor the CPRGS have been 
established at the Ministry of Planning and Investment. The working group oversees subnational 
implementation of the CPRGS; the secretariat helps provincial governments adapt the CPRGS to 
their own context and to formulate plans and budgets accordingly.  
 
5.  The State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) is responsible for formulating and implementing the 
Poverty Reduction Support Credits (PRSCs). To improve consultation and coordination with all 
stakeholders and to promote public discussion of the PRSCs, SBV is creating a special program 
coordination  unit.  Key  monitoring  programs  for  measuring  impact  on  poverty  include  the 
household living standard survey, periodic participatory poverty assessments, small business 
registration survey, public expenditure tracking survey, as well as quarterly progress reports from 
the relevant sector ministries and committees implementing the reform program. The Government 
presents its annual CPRGS progress report in December at the Consultative Group meeting. 
 
3.  Financing 
 
6.  The PRSCs provide a major ODA source of financing for CPRGS implementation. The 
PRSCs  have  attracted  sizable  grants  from  bilateral  development  partners  in  addition  to 
International  Development  Assistance  (IDA)  credits.  The  estimated  financing  gap  for  the 
implementation of the CPRGS during 2004 is US$3.3 billion, which is expected to be met by ODA 
and foreign direct investment inflows.

Appendix 2  31
4.  Progress with Implementation 
 
7.  The Government has pursued its reform agenda steadily. It recently completed the first 
annual progress report on growth and reduction of poverty for 2002–2003. The CPRGS progress 
report was presented at the Consultative Group meeting in December 2003 and indicated that 
implementation of the reform agenda was on schedule. Although considerable progress in the 
transition to a market economy has been achieved, the Government recognizes that to keep 
development  inclusive  and  to  modernize  governance,  important  challenges  remain.  Key 
recommendations  of  the  CPRGS  progress  report  include1  (i)  improve  implementation 
arrangements,  including  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  CPRGS  implementation;  (ii)  increase 
capacity building and human resource development; (iii) improve the exchange and dissemination 
of policy information regarding the CPRGS; (iv) improve statistics on poverty reduction and 
growth; (v) ensure stronger integration of the CPRGS and the 5-year and annual development 
plan in terms of targets and policies; (vi) provide more instructions for local planning; (vii) facilitate 
the participation of scientists and research institutes for in-depth analysis and multidimensional 
assessments; and (viii) align international assistance with realizing targets and measures in the 
CPRGS. 
 
8.  Over the last 12 months, the Government has adopted many substantive actions for 
implementing its socioeconomic reform agenda. It has taken steps for further trade liberalization 
in pursuit of World Trade Organization (WTO) accession and integration with the world economy. 
The Government has substantially accelerated the pace of ownership transformation of state-
owned  enterprises,  improved  the  transparency  and  accountability  in  the  financial  sector, 
strengthened  the  regulatory  framework  for  policy  lending  by  the  Government,  encouraged 
competition in telecommunications, and unified corporate tax rates.  
 
9.  In respect of social inclusion and environmental sustainability, Viet Nam has ensured 
appropriate budget allocation for education and for contribution to all the provincial (health funds 
for the poor; raised the quality standards of primary education, and adopted a multisector action 
program  to  implement  its  national  HIV/AIDS  (human  immunodeficiency  virus/acquired 
immunodeficiency syndrome) strategy. To improve environmental management, the Government 
has implemented the polluter pays principle, issued regulations to handle the worst pollution 
offenders, and strengthened the environmental assessment capacity of local administrations.  
The  new  Land  Law—effective  1  July  2004—supports  access  to  land  for  all  sectors  and 
recognizes community land-use practices—an important issue for upland and ethnic minority 
areas.  
 
10.  To  build  modern  governance,  the  Government  has  taken  measures  to  increase 
transparency in public finances, improve financial accountability, and ensure dissemination of its 
legal documents and consultation with stakeholders. It continues to move forward on public 
administration reform by simplifying administrative procedures using the one-stop shop model. It 
has taken steps to strengthen the public procurement process, and to curb abuses in business 
transactions. The Government intends to integrate the CPRGS approach into future 5-year and 1-
year planning processes. 
 
B.  Socioeconomic Performance and Key Policy Issues  
 
11.  While  the  Government  has  had  great  success  in  reducing  poverty,  regional  income 
disparity remains a concern. Coastal development and further urbanization should cater to the 
employment needs of the surplus labor coming from the hinterlands. This should also take into 
account possible restructuring and modernization of the agriculture sector.  
 
                                                 
1 Compiled from CPRGS Steering Committee, Interministerial Working Group. 2003. Viet Nam: Growth and Reduction 
of Poverty, Annual Progress Report of 2002–2003. Hanoi.

32 Appendix 2 
12.  In the past, agriculture sector growth resulted from (i) reliance on higher input use (labor, 
land, fertilizer, tractors, and irrigation); (ii) policy reforms for land, markets, and trade; and (iii) high 
public investment, mainly in irrigation and roads. This strategy will not likely be able to sustain 
growth in the future because (i) the potential for expanding the rural labor force and land under 
cultivation is limited; (ii) new investment in irrigation exhibits decreasing marginal returns, as the 
stock of irrigation capital is already very high and requires increased operation and maintenance 
rather than new expansion; and (iii) net revenue from rice export is declining. Viet Nam is already 
experiencing  overproduction  of  rice,  coffee,  and  other  commodities,  and  declining  export 
revenues from unprocessed primary commodities.  
 
13.  The Government has made a good progress in specializing in a number of agriculture and 
fishery products (for example, coffee, shrimps, catfish) and by taking advantage of increased 
market  access  to  regional  and  international  high-income  countries.  However,  predominantly 
traditional farming practices that produce relatively low-value crops are holding back further 
success.  Advanced  agriculture  technology  needs  to  be  developed  and  disseminated. 
Agribusinesses and small and medium enterprises need to be developed for agro processing to 
increase added value. Credit delivery to farmers needs to be improved, with consideration for 
introducing crop and livestock insurance schemes in collaboration with the private sector or by 
promoting a full-fledged microfinance system. 
 
14.  Carefully planned and efficiently managed large infrastructure projects such as seaports, 
airports, power plants, and national railways and roads properly linked with feeder roads and can 
actively contribute to national socioeconomic development, as well as regional and international 
economic  integration.  At  both  the  national  and  subregional  levels,  they  help  (i)  strengthen 
linkages between poor and developed regions; (ii) provide access to socioeconomic opportunities 
as  well  as  public  services;  (iii)  create  conditions  for  exploiting  local  resources  for  meeting 
national, regional, and international demands; (iv) improve connectivity between people and 
businesses;  and  (v)  eventually  facilitate  transformation  of  economic  structures  toward 
industrialization.  
 
15.  The Government has emphasized the importance of large infrastructure development in 
the context of economic growth and poverty reduction. Infrastructure development also has a 
subregional  dimension,  whereby  the  potential  demand  from  neighboring  countries/subregion 
should be taken into account. Development of large infrastructures will require large capital 
investments. Preliminary estimates suggest that in total the Government will need to invest about 
35% of gross domestic product over the next 15 years to achieve the planned growth rate of 7.5% 
2
per year.  Better project planning, implementation, and management, following internationally 
accepted good practices, coupled with necessary policy and institutional reforms to facilitate trade 
(including customs- and immigration-related reforms) will be required to ensure the expected net 
economic benefits are fully realized.   
 
16.  In  the  country  the  realization  is  growing  that  serious  environmental  degradation  and 
insufficient investment in environmental protection and management are beginning to impinge on 
the country’s economic productivity. This could adversely affect economic competitiveness, result 
in productivity losses due to pollution-related health problems in the workforce, and reduce the 
welfare and quality of life of the people. The Prime Minister approved the National Strategy for 
Environmental Protection until 2010 and Vision towards 2020 on December 2, 2003. The strategy 
outlines the rapid deterioration of the environment and offers 36 priority programs to strengthen 
environmental protection through the expected future of continued rapid industrialization and 
modernization. Viet Nam’s Agenda 21 was approved in August 2004, and a new, expanded 
environmental protection law is expected to be approved in 2005.  
 
                                                 
2 Based on the preliminary results of a recent joint study by the Government and ADB.

Appendix 2  33
17.  To achieve efficient management of its development process and poverty reduction, the 
Government  should  ensure  (i)  transparency  and  accountability  of  central  as  well  as  local 
budget/spending; (ii) proper accounting and auditing of public revenue and expenditure; (iii) 
simplification and harmonization of internal procedures at both central and provincial levels; (iv) 
accelerated implementation of the public administration reform (including computerization of state 
administration, and training of civil servants to build capacity/capabilities at local levels); and (v) 
regular  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  development  projects,  involving  beneficiaries  and  civil 
society.   
 
18.  The Government is preparing a new 5-year socioeconomic development plan (2006–
2010). The plan will be fundamentally different from the past 5-year plans. The next plan will 
anticipate further opening of the economy through the implementation of Association of South 
East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free Trade Area, bilateral agreements with the European Union, 
Japan, and the United States, and WTO commitments. This will result in increased access to 
regional and global markets, and also increased external competitive pressure (through imports) 
for domestic suppliers, which may result in short-term adjustment costs affecting mainly poor 
households.  A  major  thrust  of  the  next  5-year  plan  should  be  on  removing  development 
weaknesses and exploiting the country’s opportunities and strengths. 
  
19.  On the macroeconomic front, prudence is required to ensure stability and sustain high 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  The  Government  should  aim  to  achieve  economic 
growth from (i) more efficient utilization of existing stock of capital (i.e., improving competitiveness 
by removing inefficiencies, and maximizing capacity utilization in productive sectors); and (ii) 
efficient allocation and use of new capital investments (i.e., health and education, infrastructure 
development, modernization and restructuring of agriculture, industry and service sectors). New 
investments should ideally be maintained around 35% of the gross domestic product, above this 
level may mean excess money supply leading to high inflation and other associated problems as 
the economy may have difficulty absorbing that extent of additional capital deployment. 
 
20.  On the social front, income disparity, both geographic and demographic, will increase if 
economic growth is not socially inclusive, and policy loopholes and weak governance continue. 
Reducing poverty for the remaining 29% of the population will become increasingly difficult. ODA 
(i.e., grants and soft loans) should be targeted at developing remote areas and reducing chronic 
poverty. The implementation of the ASEAN Free Trade Area and WTO commitments (assuming 
successful WTO accession in 2005) should be carefully planned and monitored to mitigate likely 
social costs. 
 
21.  The Government has indicated that the next 5-year plan would be integrated with the 
CPRGS and the master program for public administration reform (2001–2010). This would mean 
(i) integrating CPRGS strategic and process elements into socioeconomic development planning, 
and (ii) strengthening public administration to efficiently implement Government policies and 
provide public services to people and businesses.  
C.  Chronology 
1.  Background 
 
22.  During the Country Programming Mission of ADB in April 2004, the Government formally 
asked ADB to provide financing for implementation of the CPRGS3, under the multi-development 
partner assisted PRSC III led by the World Bank.4  ADB, recognizing the importance of this 
                                                 
3 Ministry of Planning and Investment. 2003. The Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy. Hanoi. 
4  Following the joint processing of the PRSC III, the World Bank approved a US$100 million International Development 
Association credit. Details can be found in International Development Association Program document for a proposed

34 Appendix 2 
request  and  the  Government’s  commitment  to  poverty  reduction,  responded  positively. 
Subsequently,  the  proposed  program  loan  was  upgraded  to  “firm”  for  2004  in  the  Country 
Strategy and Program Update 2004,5 and endorsed by the ADB Board of Directors on 20 August 
2004.   
 
23.  Preparatory work to formulate the PRSC III was initiated in November 2003 with the 
involvement  of  key  development  partners  and  government  agencies.  ADB  was  invited  to 
participate in the formulation of the PRSC III, including in the policy discussions and negotiations 
with the Government. On behalf of the Government, SBV coordinated the overall processing of 
the PRSC III. For the development partners, the formulation process was led by the World Bank. 
 
2.  The Program Loan Proposal Formulation Process 
 
24.  From the outset, the Government and the Mission recognized the very tight timetable 
within which the ADB loan proposal had to be prepared, and the need to ensure that the program 
loan proposal be conceived as substantive, credible, and defensible. From the ADB perspective, 
for a program loan proposal, it was critical for the Government to (i) demonstrate commitment and 
support at all government levels; and (ii) facilitate the fullest possible participation by all key 
stakeholders during the formulation and implementation of the program loan. These two crucial 
conditions were accomplished during the PRSC III processing. 
   
25.  The Fact-Finding Mission from 24 August–3 September 2004, used the diagnostic work 
on the issues and challenges that the Government is seeking to address in PRSC III under the 
CPRGS framework. The mission identified the policy and institutional measures, actions, and 
implementation  arrangements  necessary  to  ensure  effective  CPRGS  implementation  utilizing 
ODA  funding.  The  mission  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  and  other 
development partners on the objectives, scope, financing, and implementation arrangements for 
the proposed loan. The Government proposed that the processing of the loan follow simplified 
procedures since ADB was one of the key development partners that had participated in the 
preparation of the CPRGS and formulation of the PRSC III; PRSC III has already been approved 
by  the  Government  and  the  World  Bank,  and  the  Government  would  also  follow  simplified 
procedure for its internal processing and approval.  
 
26.  To  reduce  transaction costs  for  the  Government  and  ADB,  the  mission  pursued  the 
possibility of applying a program-based approach in close consultation with ADB’s Strategy and

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national  Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
    agreement?     
 
The program loan will contribute to poverty reduction by supporting implementation of the Government’s 
Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS). As a multisector instrument covering a range of 
issues related to poverty reduction, the Poverty Reduction Support Credits (PRSCs) and the program loan provide an 
opportunity to advance restructuring of the economy to achieve equitable economic growth and well-being. The 
CPRGS is an important vehicle to reduce poverty and improve social service delivery and other social indicators in a 
sustainable manner. This will be achieved by implementing a broad-based reform agenda, which has its foundation on 
three key pillars: (i) transition to a market economy, (ii) social inclusion and environmental sustainability, and (iii) 
modern governance. The policy reform agenda involves trade integration, and reforms for state-owned enterprises 
(SOEs), financial sector, infrastructure, education, health, land, water, environment, planning process, public financial 
management, financial accountability, public administration, and anticorruption. These reforms are valuable essential 
contributors for achieving poverty reduction, growth, and social development in a sustainable, equitable, and cost-
effective manner. The reforms are multisector and interlinked and will have direct and indirect positive impacts on 
poverty reduction and social services delivery at all levels, at different degrees. The program loan, which follows the 
PRSC III framework, calls for accelerating the policy changes and reforms that increase efficiency, transparency, and 
accountability; and stimulate growth, thereby reducing poverty and improving social services to poor people. The 
CPRGS and thus the program loan, are consistent with the poverty reduction strategy, the Country Strategy and 
Program for Viet Nam (2002–2004), the Poverty Reduction Partnership Agreement (2002) with Viet Nam of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), and the attainment of the Viet Nam Development Goals, the country version of the 
Millennium Development Goals .  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        
        Proposed Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
A comprehensive poverty analysis was jointly carried out as background to the preparation of the PRSC III1. Viet 
Nam’s achievements in terms of social development and poverty reduction have been remarkable. Almost one third of 
total population was lifted out of poverty in less then 10 years. Poverty incidence was halved during 1993–2002. 
Economic growth underpinned the rapid poverty reduction. The elasticity of poverty reduction to economic growth was 
higher than one. 
 
The decline in poverty was widespread as the increase in inequality has been modest so far. Social indicators 
improved markedly, positioning Viet Nam well to attain key Millennium Development Goals. The last decade was thus 
characterized by undeniable progress in the lives of the Vietnamese population.  
 
Poverty incidence is high in remote mountain and highland areas and in the pockets of densely populated deltas and 
river basins.  
 
While decentralization has many advantages, the trend to decentralized government could amplify disparities between 
rich and poor regions, because rich regions have higher local resources and revenues, and thus will be able to spend 
substantially more on development and social services than the poorer regions, which are dependent on central 
Government transfers. Conscious of this phenomenon, the Government has preferential and special programs for the 
poor in these regions. Targeted programs, such as Program 135, are in place and have generally benefited the poor.  
 
To further reduce poverty and sustain the high level of economic growth, Viet Nam needs to remove structural 
weaknesses, promote socially and environmentally inclusive development, and modernize governance and the public 
administration system.
